abstract.p: Letter from Didier Jacobs (Grassroots Internatinoal) calls on international community to stop arms sales and suspend development assistance to Ethiopia pending an end to current aggression against Eritrea and resumption of negotiations in good faith

block.p: Re ''Ethiopia and Eritrea Renew Border War With Fierce Intensity'' (news article, May 15): It has become fashionable to call the Ethiopian-Eritrean war senseless and to blame both parties equally.

After shying away from exerting any meaningful pressure on either side for two years, the United Nations Security Council is now considering imposing sanctions on both countries. But it is Ethiopia that mounted a major offensive on Friday and rejected the internationally approved peace plan; by accepting this plan, Eritrea has agreed to withdraw its troops from the contested territories. In this context, sanctions against both countries defy logic and justice.
Re ''Ethiopia and Eritrea Renew Border War With Fierce Intensity'' (news article, May 15): It has become fashionable to call the Ethiopian-Eritrean war senseless and to blame both parties equally.

After shying away from exerting any meaningful pressure on either side for two years, the United Nations Security Council is now considering imposing sanctions on both countries. But it is Ethiopia that mounted a major offensive on Friday and rejected the internationally approved peace plan; by accepting this plan, Eritrea has agreed to withdraw its troops from the contested territories. In this context, sanctions against both countries defy logic and justice.

The time has come for the international community to stop arms sales and suspend development assistance to Ethiopia pending an end to the current aggression and the resumption of negotiations in good faith.
The writer is an intern at Grassroots International, a group working for social change.
